newsitem.title: USA: Third Age Web site targets growing 50+ set.
newsitem.headline: Third Age Web site targets growing 50+ set.

text.p: The startup Third Age Media is expected to formally launch its sponsor-backed Web site Monday as it aims to tap into the interests of the nation's growing numbers of wired baby boomers over 50.

Drawing on statistics that show an American turns 50 every seven seconds, a rate that's set to increase over time, Third Age is targeting the ageing baby boomer generation, which the company's president, Mike Edelhart, said has "defined what is hip and hot in the market" for years.

A Nielsen/CommerceNet report in March found that 7.6 million of the 50.6 million Internet users in North America are age 50 or older -- and this group is more likely to have more time to spend on-line, Edelhart said.

"They represent the sweet spot in the market today," he said recently, noting that those 50 and over are twice as likely to read news online and 30 percent more likely to have bought a product over the Web.
"Their lives are not at an end, but at a dramatic new beginning," Edelhart said. "Third agers crave media that reflect their active reality."
The site is one of the most focused effort to use the Internet to create affinity groups of online communities which draw people together around common interests.

Third Age founder and CEO Mary Furlong, a 48-year-old University of San Francisco professor, said the new online service aims to provide a combination of community, content and a marketplace for older individuals who are looking to make the most of their later years.
"It is like an island where people want to go in the middle of the Internet ocean -- a harbour or place that people want to come back to," she said of the concept.
Third Age Media has already lined up an extensive list of corporate sponsors -- ranging from Quaker Oats to Toys "R" Us -- to provide sponsorship, advertising and products over through the site.
In addition to its site (http://www.thirdage.com), Third Age has also rounded up partnerships with Yahoo Inc., Microsoft Corp.'s Microsoft Network, MSN, and Netscape Communications Corp..
Third Age provides a daily news and features package to Microsoft, produces the Seniors Forum on MSN and is a participant in Netscape's In-Box Direct programme.
Third Age also produces a news service distributed by Universal Press Syndicate to more than 200 newspapers.

On its own Web site, sponsors will provide a variety of offerings, ranging from an online dating and personals service from Match.com to books from Amazon.com, which like many sponsors will be offering discounts.
Toys "R" Us is developing a co-branded area with Third Age to be dubbed Grandparents R Us, including features on grandparenting and gift ideas for grandchildren.

Hallmark Cards Inc.'s technology brand, Hallmark Connections, is sponsoring a "Share a Moment" area where people who enter the Third Age site can share stories and send electronic greetings with family and friends.
Other products and services range from financial research publications to video phone products and direct delivery of grocery and produce to homes in seven cities.

Furlong was founder and president of SeniorNet, a non- profit membership organisation dedicated to educating older adults about computer technology, and served for ten years as president of the organisation.

The company raised $3 million in first round financing in January from Softbank, Advance Publications and nearly two dozen individual investors and is currently looking to raise up to $8 million in a further round.

Furlong said the company is targeting to become cash flow positive in 1998 and to achieve profitability a year later, with the prospect of an initial public offering perhaps in a three to five year range.
